TOOLTIP_TEXT.CURRENT_BASE_METRICS:
Statistics reported in Current Base metrics: 
- startTime              - ipAddress
- endTime                - portNumber
- timeZoneOffset         - inboundPacketCount
- callCompletionCode     - inboundByteCount
- proprietoryErrorCode   - outboundPacketCount
- sequenceNumber         - outboundByteCount
- uniqueCallId           - packetDelayVariation
- hostName               - averagePacketLatency
- subscriberID           - packetLossPercentage/Loss Rate
- originalDestinationId  - inboundLostPacketCount (Non H.248 GWs)
TOOLTIP_TEXT.RTP_BASE_REMOTE_METRICS:
Statistics reported in RTP Base Remote metrics: 
- inboundPacketCount
- inboundByteCount
- outboundPacketCount
- outboundByteCount
- packetDelayVariation
- packetLossPercentage/Loss Rate
- inboundLostPacketCount
TOOLTIP_TEXT.EXTRA_BASE_METRICS:
Statistics reported in Extra Base metrics: 
- local bearer IP
- remote bearer IP
- local bearer port
- remote bearer Port
- local bearer i/f
- VBD Flag
- number of Fax pages received 
- number of Fax pages sent 
- Average Jitter

- preferred codec
- final negotiated Codec

Statistics reported in Voice Quality Monitor block: 
- Conversational R
- Listening R
- MOS-LQ
- MOS-CQ
TOOLTIP_TEXT.V_Q_DEBUG_METRIC:
Statistics reported in Voice Quality Debug block: 
- End System Delay
- Signal Level
- Noise Level
- Residual Echo Return Loss
- PLC Config
TOOLTIP_TEXT.LOSS_DEBUG_METRIC:
Statistics reported in Loss Debug block: 
- Discard Rate
- Burst Duration
- Burst Density
- Gap Duration
- Gap Density
- Network Packet Loss Rate
- Gap Threshold setting
TOOLTIP_TEXT.UNIT_STIM_SPECIFIC_METRIC:
Statistics reported in Unistim Specific block: 
- PLC Effectiveness                        - Burst Count
- Round Trip Time Average High Water Mark  - Gap R Factor
- Maximum One Way Delay in MS              - Burst R Factor
- Average Network Loss Rate                - Frames per Packet (ptime)
- Inter-arrival Jitter HWM                 - MIU Duplicate Percentage
- Packets Out of Order                     - silenceSuppression
TOOLTIP_TEXT.JITTER_DEBUG_METRIC:

OVERVIEW.TITLE: Overview
OVERVIEW.FUNCTIONAL_DESCRIPTION_BODY:
The GWC acts as a protocol translator to translate proprietary DMS-based messages and transactions to standard third-party messages sent to GWCs within the same Communications Server or to GWC's on another Communications Server. The GWC is responsible for all communication between the Core and media gateways for call control.

A GWC node consists of two gateway controller units. The first unit, unit 0 is active while the second unit, unit 1 is in hot standby mode, ready to take over should the active unit fail or when a manual action takes place.

For VC20 solutions, GWCs are provisioned as applications running on VMs.

The Gateway Controllers (GWCs) are an integral part of C20. The GWCs provide the capability for:
  • inter-C20 Network calls using the Session Initiation Protocol for Telephony (SIP-T) messaging across the packet network to enable inter-C20 functionality.
  • intra-C20 Network using IUAP, MGCP, ASPEN, H.323 and MEGACO/H.248 signaling protocols that talk to the gateway.
The Gateway Controller provides protocol mediation between the Core and the media gateways. The GWCs can function as an interface between the Core and third-party peripherals. The Core views the Gateway Controller as another peripheral from a call processing, messaging, and control point of view. Additionally, media gateways and the Core view the Gateway Controller as a Media Gateway Controller; therefore, the Gateway Controller connects the two views together.

Messages from the Gateway Controller to the media gateways trigger the setup of the media path. Using fabric control messages from the Core, ingress and egress Gateway Controllers can exchange connection information that allows them to send control messages to the correct media gateway.
OVERVIEW.VC20_BODY: Gateway Controllers run as applications on VMs. The Data Manager provides management of the VMs.

NETWORK_CONFIGURATION.TITLE: Network Configuration
NETWORK_CONFIGURATION.FUNCTIONAL_DESCRIPTION_BODY: The Network Configuration panel shows the current network configuration settings for Gateway Controllers and is displayed when the GatewayController device type is selected.
NETWORK_CONFIGURATION.FUNCTIONAL_DESCRIPTION_INFO: If using an Operations Support System (OSS), selection of the GatewayController device type may not be necessary, as this panel may be displayed automatically when Network Configuration details are requested.  In this case, the various Device Types will not be displayed.
NETWORK_CONFIGURATION.GENERAL_NETWORK_SETTINGS_BODY:
Include the default domain name for gateway controllers, the Call Agent identifier for this Call Server and the auto-imaging function. The values can be modified via the "General Network Setting " button.

Use this procedure to initially set or change the General Network settings for the network.
  1. Complete the required fields.
    Note: The Call Agent Identifier must be set if middleboxes provisioned for this Call Server are shared with other Call Servers.
  2. Click the OK button to confirm the request, or the Cancel button to abort the request. If one or more Gateway Controllers fail the update, a dialog is presented with detailed results.

DEVICES.BODY: Network Devices shows all the network devices that can be provisioned.

QOS_COLLECTORS.BODY: Qos Collectors may be added and deleted by the buttons located under the QoS Collectors panel. Refer to the following procedures for information on these functions:
QOS_COLLECTORS.ADD_QOS_COLLECTOR_BODY:
Use this procedure to add a QoS Collector.
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Select the QoS Collectors tabbed panel, and click the "New QoS Collector" button to display the Add QoS Collector dialog.
  3. Enter the QoS Collector Name, Ip Address, and port.
  4. Click the OK button to confirm the request, or the Cancel button to abort the request.
  5. The QoS Collector will appear in the list following successful addition.
QOS_COLLECTORS.DELETE_QOS_COLLECTOR_BODY:
Use this procedure to delete a QoS Collector.
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Select the QoS Collectors tabbed panel.
  3. Select a QoS Collector from the list and click the Delete button.
  4. Click the Yes button to confirm the request, or the No button to abort the request.
  5. The QoS Collector will be removed from the list following successful deletion.

ALGS.BODY: An Application Layer Gateway (ALG) may be added, changed and deleted by the buttons located under the ALGs panel. Refer to the following procedures for information on these functions:
ALGS.ADD_ALG_BODY:
Use this procedure to add an Application Layer Gateway (ALG).
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Click on the ALGs tab, and click the "New ALG"button to display the Add ALG dialogue.
  3. Enter a Name that identifies the FQDN and the associated IP Address. The Port field is provided but may be modified by entering a different value. The Protocol is pre-defined to NCS and not modifiable. Currently only NCS is supported.
  4. Click the OK button to confirm the request, or the Cancel button to abort the request.
  5. The server will appear in the list following successful addition.
ALGS.CHANGE_ALG_BODY:
Use this procedure to change Application Layer Gateway (ALG) server attributes.
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Select an ALG from the list and click the Edit icon.
  3. Enter your changes to the IP address and Port
  4. Click the OK button to confirm the request, or the Cancel button to abort the request.
  5. The server list is updated following a successful change.
ALGS.DELETE_ALG_BODY:
Use this procedure to delete an Application Layer Gateway (ALG).
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Select an ALG from the list and click the Delete icon.
  3. Click the OK button to confirm the request, or the Cancel button to abort the request.
  4. The server will be removed from the list following successful deletion.

PEP_SERVERS.BODY: Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) servers provide subscriber control mechanisms needed for setting up calls with DQoS or Admission Control quality. PEP servers may be added, modified, and deleted by the buttons located under the PEP Servers panel. Refer to the following procedures for information on these functions:
PEP_SERVERS.ADD_PEP_SERVER_BODY:
Use this procedure to add a Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) server.
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Click on the PEP Servers tabbed pane, and click the "New Pep Server" button to display the Add PEP Server dialog.
  3. Enter a Name that identifies the FQDN and the associated IP Address. Type is pre-defined to DQoS Middle Box (dqosmb). Max connections is the maximum number of gateway controllers this server can be associated with. It is defaulted to 10, but can be set as required. Protocol Version corresponds to which version of the DQOS Protocol the Pep has implemented. Currently, the supported versions are DQOS I04 and DQOS I03. For more information, see the corresponding DQOS specifications at www.packetcable.com.
  4. Click the OK button to confirm the request, or the Cancel button to abort the request.
  5. The server will appear in the list following successful addition.
PEP_SERVERS.CHANGE_PEP_SERVER_BODY:
Use this procedure to change Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) server attributes.
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Select a PEP server from the list and click the Edit icon.
  3. Enter your changes to the IP address, Max connections, and/or Protocol version.
  4. Click the OK button to confirm the request, or the Cancel button to abort the request.
  5. The server list is updated following a successful change.
PEP_SERVERS.DELETE_PEP_SERVER_BODY:
Use this procedure to delete a Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) server.
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Select a PEP server from the list and click the Delete icon.
  3. Click the Yes button to confirm the request, or the No button to abort the request.
  4. The server will be removed from the list following successful deletion.

NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE.BODY:
Network Codec Profile is added/changed/deleted via the Network Codec Profiletabbed pane.
Refer to the following procedures for information on these functions: Add a Network Codec Profile, Change the Network Codec Profile and Delete a Network Codec Profile.
NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE.ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_INFO: The network codec profile must be configured before the addition of Gateway Controllers.

ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.DEFINITION: Use this procedure to add a Network Codec Profile.
ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.FIRST: Click on the Network Codec Profile tabbed pane, and click the "New Profile" button to display the Add Network Codec Profile dialog.
ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.SECOND: The Add Network Codec Profile dialog box is displayed.
ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.THIRD: Enter a valid Profile Name. The Max length of the name is 32 characters.

FOURTH.BODY: Select a Bearer Network Type from the pull-down menu if different from the default or the previously selected choice. The choices are:
FOURTH.AAL1: AAL1(packet trunking over ATM for international markets)
FOURTH.AAL2: AAL2 (packet trunking over ATM for North American markets)

ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.FIFTH: Select the Codec combination for this profile.You can add codec into the selection by selecting the codec and clicking the Add >> button, and delete it by clicking <You can select up to 3 codecs in every profile. The following table shows all available codec combinations which are supported in this system currently.

SIXTH.BODY: Select a Packetization Rate from the pull-down menu if different from the default or the previously selected choice. The choices are:

SEVENTH.BODY: Enable/disable Local Control Options T.38, RFC2833 and Confort Noise via the check boxes, which are sent by gateway controllers when sending messages to NCS and MGCP protocol gateways.
SEVENTH.FIRST_NOTE: Combo box is now used to list the T-38 options for NCS and MGCP protocol gateway. The options are OFF, ON (Strict), and LOOSE. Prior to SN09, the only choice for T.38 was enabled or disabled. The equivalent for enabled is ON(Strict) and for disable(OFF). The third option, "LOOSE" is only use for packet cable.
SEVENTH.SECOND_NOTE: The Local Control Options are enabled only if the Bearer Network Type is set to IP.

ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.EIGHTHT: Enable the Set as bearer type default setting if you want this one to be the default profile on this bearer network.
ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.NINTH: Enable the Set as network default setting if you want this one to be the network default profile.
ADD_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.TENTH: Click the OK button to add this profile, or Cancel to abort this operation.

NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE.CHANGE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_INFO: Profile name and bearer network type can not be changed.
NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE.CHANGE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY:
Use this procedure to change a Network Codec Profile.
  1. Click on the Network Codec Profile tabbed pane, select the profile to be changed, and click the Change icon to display the Change Network Codec Profile dialog.
  2. The Change Network Codec Profile dialog box is displayed.
  3. Change the Codec Selection as needed. Please refer to Add Network Codec Profile for valid codec combinations. Also, Packetization Rate and local options (T-38, RFC2833, Comfort Noise) will be enabled if the bearer network type is IP, and these can be changed as needed.
  4. Click the Save button to apply this change, or Cancel to abort it. The Network Codec Profile tabbed panel will be refreshed automatically.
  5. If you are changing a profile which is used by some Gateway Controllers, the new setting will be sent to all of the associated devices automatically when you apply the change. In the event that one or more of the associated devices is not communicating, a warning dialog will be displayed indicating which devices are impacted and the steps required to complete the operation.
NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE.DELETE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_INFO: Only profiles that have not been used by any Gateway Controller can be deleted.

DELETE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.DEFINITION: Use this procedure to delete a Network Codec Profile.
DELETE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.SECOND: Click on the Network Codec Profile tabbed pane, select the profile to be deleted, and click the "Delete" icon.
DELETE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.THIRD: The Delete Network Codec Profile Confirmation dialog box is displayed.
DELETE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.FOURTH: Click the Yes button to delete this profile, or No to abort this operation. The Network Codec Profile tabbed panel will be refreshed automatically.
DELETE_NETWORK_CODEC_PROFILE_BODY.FIFTH: If the profile is used by any Gateway Controller, the delete operation will fail, and an error message will be displayed.

DQOS_CONF.DQOS_CONF_DEF: The DQoS Configuration defines values used in the DQOS protocol between GWC and PEP Servers. These settings are associated with PacketCable Dynamic Quality of Service (DQoS) which is a capability to control the quality of service in the access portion of a PacketCable Network. The PacketCable Gateway can have a Quality of Service (QoS) up to the level authorized by the gateway controller. These values are applicable to the entire system. The DQoS Configuration is set/modified via the Change... button located under the DQoS Configuration table. Refer to the Change DQoS Configuration procedure for more information.
DQOS_CONF.CHANGE_DQOS_BODY:
Use this procedure to initially set or change the DQoS Configuration data for the network.
  1. Display the Network Configuration panel.
  2. Select the DQoS Configuration table.
  3. Complete the required fields.
  4. Click the Save button to confirm the request, or the Reset button to reload the current values. If one or more Gateway Controllers fail the update, a dialog is presented with detailed results.
